alt_statements.statement: At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we ignore pollution and climate risks, and it’s always the most vulnerable communities who pay the highest price. I believe climate policy should put environmental protection first, but do it in a way that invests in new, clean industries, supports workers through the transition, and creates good jobs—especially in local communities. We don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a healthy economy; a well-planned green transition is actually the smartest long-term economic strategy.

I think we need a realistic balance where we protect the environment without crippling jobs, small businesses, and family budgets. Climate policy should focus on practical solutions like cleaner technology, energy efficiency, and responsible regulations that don’t skyrocket energy prices or shut down entire industries overnight. We have a duty to be good stewards of God’s creation, but also to make sure working families can provide for their kids and have a stable, growing economy.

As someone who works in healthcare and spends a lot of my free time outdoors watching birds, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply intertwined rather than competing goals. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and protect ecosystems, because the long-term health costs and economic damage from climate change far outweigh the short-term profits of polluting industries. That said, we should invest heavily in clean energy, green infrastructure, and worker retraining so that the transition strengthens the middle class and creates stable, well-paying jobs. In my view, if economic growth isn’t sustainable and equitable, it’s not real progress.

Como mujer que trabaja duro en un supermercado y que ha tenido que empezar de nuevo en este país, creo que cuidar el medioambiente es muy importante, pero no se puede hacer de una forma que deje a la gente sin trabajo o que suba demasiado el costo de la vida. Las políticas sobre el clima deben ser prácticas, graduales y enfocadas en soluciones que también ayuden a la economía, como apoyar a las pequeñas empresas, mejorar el transporte público y promover energías más limpias sin castigar a los que menos tenemos.

Working in healthcare, I see how environmental conditions directly affect people’s health, so I think climate policy has to prioritize protecting our air, water, and long‑term wellbeing, even if that means some short‑term economic tradeoffs. That said, I don’t believe it’s an either/or choice: with smart planning and investment, we can create good jobs in cleaner industries while phasing out the most harmful practices. Economic growth that undermines public health and damages communities isn’t real progress, but growth that respects environmental limits can be both sustainable and beneficial.

I think we’ve got to take climate change seriously, but we also can’t just pull the rug out from under people who depend on steady jobs and affordable energy. To me the right balance is investing in cleaner technologies and energy efficiency in a way that supports American businesses and workers, rather than burdening them with sudden, heavy regulations. I’m fine with strong environmental standards as long as they’re practical, phased in over time, and based on solid data instead of politics.

Given what I see in my work, I don’t buy the idea that environmental protection and economic growth are opposites—climate disasters are already incredibly expensive, and they’re only going to get worse if we don’t act. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions and resilience measures, even if that means short‑term costs, because the long‑term economic and human toll of inaction is far higher. The right balance is to set strong, science-based environmental standards and then give businesses clear, stable rules and incentives to innovate within that framework.

As someone who cares a lot about the environment and plans to live on this planet for many decades, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, but not in a way that ignores people’s jobs and basic needs. Instead of treating the environment and the economy like opposites, we should invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and retraining programs so that workers and communities—especially those already struggling—benefit from the transition. In the long run, a healthy economy depends on a healthy planet, so real economic growth has to be sustainable, not based on burning through resources and worsening climate change.

As someone who works in a state-run food service and cares deeply about my community, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection first while still respecting the need for stable jobs and economic security. We can’t keep chasing short-term growth if it destroys the air, water, and climate our neighborhoods depend on, but we also have to invest in a just transition—training workers, especially in working-class and immigrant communities, for cleaner, better-paying jobs. For me, real economic growth means healthier communities, more resilient local food systems, and policies that hold big polluters accountable instead of leaving ordinary people to pay the price.

As a working mom and the primary earner for my family, I believe climate policy has to protect both the environment and the livelihoods of people who depend on industries like mine. We should invest in realistic, market-driven technologies that reduce emissions over time—like efficiency improvements and cleaner production—without killing jobs or driving up costs for families. I’m for conservation and responsible stewardship of the planet, but I don’t support extreme regulations that hurt small businesses and American competitiveness while countries like China keep polluting.

I think we should protect nature first, because if the air, water, and animals get too hurt, people can’t live good lives or have jobs anyway. Grown-ups should make rules so companies don’t pollute too much, but also help them use clean energy so they can still make money and parents can keep their jobs.

We need to protect the land and water God gave us, but we also have to be realistic about people’s livelihoods and the cost of living. Climate policy should focus on practical measures that don’t destroy jobs or make energy unaffordable for working people and seniors on fixed incomes. I support gradual, market-based solutions and better technology, not heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses and raise everyone’s bills.

I think we should protect nature first, because if the air, water, and animals get ruined, money won’t really matter and kids like me won’t have a safe place to grow up. Grown‑ups should still try to help people keep their jobs, but they should use their smarts and new ideas to make clean energy and green businesses so families can have both a good life and a healthy Earth that God gave us to take care of.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin the planet there won’t be any economy left for my generation to grow up in. That said, climate policies should also help create new kinds of jobs and technologies so people don’t lose their livelihoods. We should invest in clean energy, public transit, and greener businesses, so we can cut pollution while still letting communities and families like mine have stable futures.

Look, I make a living driving people around, so I see both sides: we need clean air and a stable climate, but we also can’t crush working folks and small businesses with expensive rules dreamed up by people who never had to worry about a fuel bill. I’m all for realistic, market-based solutions—like incentives for cleaner cars and tech—rather than heavy-handed mandates and taxes that hit drivers and regular families first. Let companies innovate, let people choose what works for them, and focus on practical steps that cut pollution without strangling the economy. Environmental protection matters, but it shouldn’t come at the cost of people’s ability to work, provide for their kids, and live their lives.

I think we need to treat environmental protection and economic growth as partners, not enemies. We should invest in cleaner energy, better public transit, and energy-efficient infrastructure in a way that creates stable, good-paying jobs and doesn’t pull the rug out from under working families or local governments. I’m fine with stricter regulations as long as they’re phased in reasonably, based on solid science, and paired with support for businesses and communities to adapt.

Coming from Colorado and working in education-focused tours, I see firsthand how much local economies depend on natural beauty—and how fragile that is if we don’t protect the environment. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with strong regulations and investments in clean energy and green jobs, because long-term economic growth depends on a stable climate and healthy ecosystems. We can’t treat it like a trade-off between the planet and paychecks; smart policy can do both, but it has to start by respecting environmental limits.

As someone who came from Cambodia to build a better life here, I believe we should protect the environment in a way that doesn’t punish hardworking families and small businesses. Climate policies need to focus on practical solutions like encouraging cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and supporting innovation in the private sector, rather than heavy-handed regulations that raise prices and cost people their jobs. We can be good stewards of God’s creation while still promoting strong economic growth and opportunity, especially for immigrants and working-class Americans.

As someone raising kids on a tight income and running a tiny grocery store, I don’t think we can pretend the economy and the environment are separate things—if we wreck the land and climate, our jobs, food, and health go with it. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, but in a way that helps small businesses and low‑income families transition, like supporting local farms, affordable clean energy, and practical, cost‑saving changes instead of heavy new burdens.

I’ve worked the land my whole life, and I know you can’t keep taking from the soil or the air without giving something back, or it’ll quit on you. That said, we can’t be shutting down farms, small businesses, and energy jobs in the name of climate policy cooked up by folks who never got dirt under their nails. We need practical, affordable steps that cut waste and pollution—like better equipment, smarter water use, and sensible energy improvements—without strangling the rural economy or driving up costs for people on fixed incomes. Protect God’s creation, yes, but do it in a way that keeps food on the table and towns alive.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment because it’s the only one we’ve got, but we also have to be realistic about people needing steady work to support their families. Climate policies should push companies toward cleaner practices and new technologies, but in a way that doesn’t suddenly shut down factories or wipe out whole communities. I’d like to see more investment in cleaner equipment and energy for existing industries, so folks like me can keep working while we gradually cut pollution. That seems like a fair balance between responsibility to the planet and responsibility to working people.

I think we should protect nature first, because if the air and water get too dirty, people and animals will get sick and we won’t have a nice world to grow up in. Grown-ups can still make money by making cleaner things, like cars that don’t pollute as much and houses that use less energy, so the economy can grow in a way that doesn’t hurt the planet.

Working in finance, I see every day that ignoring climate risks is ultimately bad for the economy, not just the environment. Climate policy should prioritize strong environmental protection while using market-based tools and smart regulation to drive innovation and create stable, long-term growth. We don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a healthy economy—responsible investments in clean energy and resilient infrastructure can do both, especially if we support workers and communities in the transition. As a Democrat and a person of faith, I see caring for creation and planning prudently for the future as both a moral and a practical obligation.

As someone who works in public education and sees how environmental stress and economic insecurity both affect kids’ mental health, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals. We need climate policies that aggressively reduce emissions and protect natural spaces, while also investing in stable, local jobs—especially in schools, healthcare, and green infrastructure—so communities aren’t left behind. Short-term economic gains that damage the environment will ultimately cost us far more, both financially and psychologically, so “growth” has to be redefined around long-term community well-being, not just profit.

Coming from North Carolina and working campus security, I see firsthand how extreme heat and storms can disrupt students’ lives and the local economy, so I don’t buy the idea that we have to choose between the environment and jobs. A smart climate policy should invest in clean energy, public transit, and building upgrades in ways that create stable, good-paying work, especially for Black communities that have been hit hardest by pollution and inequality. As a progressive and a Christian, I feel we have a moral duty to be good stewards of creation while making sure the clean-energy transition doesn’t leave working people behind.

As a nurse and a mom, I see every day how health, especially for kids, is directly tied to clean air, safe water, and a stable climate, so environmental protection can’t be treated as optional or secondary. At the same time, I know families depend on steady jobs and a strong economy, so climate policy should push for cleaner technologies and energy solutions that create good, long-term work rather than just shutting things down overnight. I support policies that phase in strong environmental standards with realistic timelines, invest in healthcare and education, and make sure working families aren’t the ones paying the highest price for this transition.

As a working single mom and property manager, I see both sides of this issue every day: people need good jobs and affordable places to live, but we also need clean air, water, and a stable climate for our kids’ future. Climate policy should treat environmental protection and economic growth as linked, not competing—investing in energy-efficient buildings, green infrastructure, and clean tech can create solid middle-class jobs while cutting emissions. We should hold big polluters accountable and offer incentives and support for businesses and property owners to go greener, especially in working- and middle-class communities. That’s the kind of practical, long-term balance that actually helps families like mine instead of just protecting short-term profits.

As a scientist in pharmaceutical manufacturing and a mother, I see no real long‑term tradeoff between environmental protection and economic growth—unchecked climate damage will ultimately be far more costly than the investments we make now. Climate policy should set strong, science-based limits on emissions and pollution, then encourage innovation and clean industry so companies can compete and grow within those boundaries.

As someone who works in public safety and spends a lot of time outdoors with my kids, I see environmental protection as a core part of keeping our communities safe and healthy, not something separate from the economy. We should prioritize strong climate action—clean energy, efficient public transit, and resilient infrastructure—because it creates good jobs, reduces long‑term costs from disasters, and gives our kids a livable future. Economic growth that comes from polluting industries is a short-term gain with long-term damage, so our policies should clearly favor sustainable growth over quick profit.

My mommy and daddy tell me we have to take care of the air and trees so I can keep playing outside and be healthy, so I think that’s really important. I don’t understand money or jobs yet, but if people make things and build things, they should do it in a way that doesn’t make the sky dirty or hurt animals.

Como alguien que trabaja en la construcción y vive de proyectos que mueven la economía, sé que el crecimiento es importante, pero también veo que sin un medio ambiente sano no hay futuro ni trabajo para nadie. Creo que la política climática debe empujar a modernizar la industria con energías limpias y mejores estándares, creando empleos bien pagados en el proceso, no sólo poniendo trabas. El gobierno debería apoyar con capacitación y ayudas para que empresas y trabajadores podamos adaptarnos, en lugar de elegir entre cuidar el planeta o mantener nuestros sueldos.

As someone who lived through years of medical practice and understands both science and real-world tradeoffs, I believe we must protect the environment in ways that are practical and don’t cripple working families or small businesses. Climate policy should encourage innovation, responsible energy use, and conservation—especially through market-based solutions—while keeping energy reliable and affordable. We’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but also to safeguard people’s livelihoods, so I favor a balanced approach that moves us toward cleaner technologies without heavy-handed regulations that hurt the economy.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime running businesses and caring about personal health, I believe climate policy has to protect the environment in a way that doesn’t cripple the economy or punish working people. We should prioritize market-driven innovation, cleaner technologies, and practical regulations that reduce pollution without smothering growth or driving jobs overseas. A strong economy is what funds better technology, infrastructure, and resilience, so the goal should be smart, efficient climate measures that keep America competitive while being good stewards of God’s creation.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because without a healthy planet there won’t even be an economy for my generation to grow up into. That doesn’t mean we ignore jobs and businesses, but climate policy should push companies and governments to create green jobs, cleaner energy, and sustainable tech instead of just letting them pollute for short‑term profit. If we invest in things like renewable energy and public transit now, it can help the economy grow in a way that’s actually fair to people and to nature.

As someone who’s spent a life teaching and now volunteers in a community garden, I think we’ve misunderstood the choice: a healthy environment is the foundation of any real, lasting economy. Climate policy should put environmental protection first—rapid emissions cuts, protection of ecosystems, and strong regulations—while supporting workers and communities through a just transition into green jobs and more localized, sustainable industries. We’ve tried putting short-term profit ahead of the planet for decades, and it’s left us with unstable weather, fragile supply chains, and hollowed-out communities; it’s time economic growth serves ecological limits, not the other way around.

As someone who spent a career serving and protecting my community, I believe we have a duty to be good stewards of the environment, but we also have to keep our economy strong and protect people’s livelihoods. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-driven solutions that encourage cleaner energy and conservation without overregulating small businesses or driving up costs for working families. I support gradual, realistic changes that balance environmental responsibility with economic stability, so we don’t burden future generations with debt or weakened local economies in the name of progress.

A mí me gusta mucho jugar afuera en el parque y ver los árboles, los pajaritos y los bichitos, así que quiero que cuidemos la tierra para que siempre haya lugares lindos para correr y explorar. Los grandes pueden hacer dinero y tener trabajos, pero tienen que hacerlo sin ensuciar el aire y el agua, para que los niños como yo podamos crecer sanos y seguir disfrutando de la creación de Dios.

As someone who worked hard my whole life in construction and lives on a modest retirement, I believe climate policy has to protect both God’s creation and people’s ability to make an honest living. We should invest in cleaner technologies and energy sources, but do it in a way that doesn’t crush small businesses, raise bills too high for working families and seniors, or wipe out good jobs. I trust more in local communities, private innovation, and common‑sense regulations than in heavy-handed federal mandates that can hurt the economy. Environmental protection is important, but it needs to be balanced with practical policies that keep America strong and working people secure.

As someone who worked hard for years as a teacher and now lives on a modest, hard-earned income, I believe climate policy has to protect both the environment God entrusted to us and the jobs that keep American families stable. We should invest in cleaner technologies and reasonable regulations, but not in a way that crushes small businesses, raises energy costs too fast, or ships good jobs overseas. A balanced approach would encourage innovation and conservation, while keeping our economy strong enough that working people—and retirees like me—aren’t left to carry an unfair burden.

As someone who works in education, makes a good living, and spends much of my free time outdoors with my family, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals, but I do think environmental limits have to come first. If we degrade the ecosystems we depend on, any short-term economic gains are meaningless, and our kids will pay the price. Climate policy should set strong, science-based regulations and invest heavily in clean energy and conservation, while helping workers and communities transition so that a sustainable economy becomes the foundation for long-term prosperity.

As someone who works a regular job and doesn’t make a lot, I think climate policy has to protect both the planet and people like me who are just trying to get by. We should push hard for clean energy and environmental protections, but pair them with good jobs, job training, and support so workers and low-income communities don’t get left behind. I’d rather see us invest in green infrastructure, public transit, and energy-efficient buildings than keep propping up polluting industries that hurt our health and neighborhoods. Economic growth should come from making our world cleaner and fairer, not from cutting corners on the environment.

As a small business owner who depends on both affordable materials and a healthy local environment, I think climate policy has to respect economic freedom while still setting clear, practical rules that keep our air and water clean. We should focus on innovation and market-based incentives—like tax breaks for energy-efficient equipment and streamlined permits for cleaner technologies—rather than heavy-handed regulations that punish businesses. If government gets out of the way enough for entrepreneurs to solve problems creatively, we can grow the economy and reduce emissions without sacrificing individual liberty or strangling family-run shops like mine.

I think we should protect nature a lot because I like playing outside, and if the air and weather get worse, kids won’t have safe places to play. Grown-ups still need jobs and money, but they should try to make those jobs help the Earth too, like using cleaner energy and not wasting things. God made the world, so we should take care of it while still making sure families can have what they need.

I think we should protect the environment first, because if we ruin the Earth, there won’t be a good place for anyone to work or make money anyway. Grown-ups should use their businesses and science to make cleaner energy and less pollution, even if it costs more at the start, because God gave us this world to take care of, not just to use up.

As a researcher who spends a lot of time thinking in systems and long-term tradeoffs, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—unchecked climate damage is itself a massive economic risk, especially for vulnerable communities like many Black neighborhoods that have historically borne the brunt of pollution. Climate policy should put strict, science-based limits on emissions and ecological harm, and then channel innovation, public investment, and market incentives into building a clean-energy economy that creates high-quality jobs and shared prosperity. In other words, we ought to accept short-term costs and structural changes now to avoid far greater social and economic losses later, while explicitly prioritizing justice and equity in who benefits and who’s protected.

As someone who works in healthcare and is raising young kids, I think we can’t afford to treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, and smart policy can encourage cleaner industries and good jobs at the same time. I support climate policies that set clear, science-based standards and timelines, but also give businesses incentives and flexibility to innovate rather than just punishing them. For me, the priority is protecting our children’s long-term health and future, while making sure working families like mine aren’t crushed by sudden costs or job losses during the transition.

As a mom, a Catholic, and someone who makes a living in a tech-related industry, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we should be investing in cleaner technologies and energy so we create good jobs while safeguarding the planet our kids will inherit. Government has a real role to play in setting strong standards and offering incentives that push businesses to innovate, not just cut corners. If we’re smart about it, climate policy can support working families like mine by driving new industries, keeping communities healthy, and making sure no one gets left behind in the transition.

At my age, I’ve seen enough Minnesota winters to know the climate is changing, and we can’t pretend that endless economic growth matters more than clean air, safe water, and a livable planet for our grandchildren. I think we should treat environmental protection as a non-negotiable foundation, then design smart, gradual transitions—like investing in green jobs, better transit, and energy-efficient homes—so that workers, farmers, and small businesses aren’t left behind. Real prosperity, as I see it, means healthy communities, good schools, and a stable climate, not just short-term profits.

As someone who works in holistic health, I see the environment as the foundation of our collective well-being, so climate policy has to put strong environmental protection first rather than treating it as an afterthought to economic growth. That said, I don’t think it’s an either/or choice: we should invest in green industries, regenerative agriculture, and clean energy that create good jobs while reducing pollution and climate risk. A truly healthy economy is one that lives within ecological limits and supports long-term physical, mental, and community health, not just short-term profit.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be a good future for anyone’s jobs or money anyway. But I don’t think we should just shut everything down; we should use science and new technology to make cleaner energy so people can still work and support their families. Governments and businesses should invest more in things like solar and wind power, even if it costs more now, because it will pay off later for both the Earth and the economy.

I think we’ve got to stop treating environmental protection and economic growth like they’re enemies, because for people like me running a tiny tailoring shop, climate disasters and pollution hurt our livelihoods too. I’d support strong climate policies that push cleaner energy and local sustainability, as long as they include help for small businesses and workers to adapt—like grants, affordable upgrades, and training. If we do it right, we can create new kinds of work in our communities, protect our health and weather, and still keep local economies thriving.

As a healthcare professional and small business owner, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply interconnected rather than competing goals. Climate policy should aggressively reduce emissions and protect public health, while also supporting businesses—especially in healthcare and other essential services—through incentives, clear regulations, and investment in clean technologies. As a liberal and a parent, I’m willing to accept short-term economic adjustments and higher standards if it means a healthier, more stable climate and lower disease burden for my kids’ generation. The right balance is strong, science-based environmental protections paired with smart economic tools that help workers and communities transition rather than be left behind.

As a police officer and a dad, I see climate policy as a public safety and long-term stability issue, but I also know my community depends on steady jobs and a strong local economy. We should focus on practical, market-driven solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technologies and energy efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that could hurt working families. The goal ought to be measurable environmental progress that doesn’t cripple small businesses or raise costs so much that people can’t keep up. Responsible innovation and gradual transitions, not drastic mandates, are the right balance.

As a working mom and homeowner in the Midwest, I see climate policy as something that has to protect both our kids’ future and our family’s paycheck. We need strong environmental protections that push us toward clean energy and resilient communities, but they should come with smart incentives and job training so regular people—especially those in housing, construction, and real estate—aren’t left behind. I think we can grow the economy by investing in green infrastructure and energy-efficient buildings, and that’s where good policy can turn climate responsibility into economic opportunity.

I like when trees and animals are safe, and I want the air to stay clean so I can play outside without getting sick. Grown‑ups should make sure we don’t hurt the Earth too much, even if it means changing how we make things or spend money, because the planet is our home and we need it for a long, long time.

I think we should protect the environment first, because this is the only planet we have and my friends and I have to live here when we grow up. It’s okay if some things cost more or take longer to build as long as they don’t ruin the air, water, and animals. Grown‑ups can still make money and jobs by inventing cleaner ways to do stuff instead of just using things that hurt the Earth.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because my generation is the one that will live with the worst effects of climate change, and low-income communities and people of color usually get hit the hardest. But I don’t think that means we should ignore jobs or the economy—climate policy should invest in clean energy, green jobs, and better public transit so people can have good work while we cut pollution.

At my age, I’ve seen that when we put profit before people and the planet, it’s always the most vulnerable who pay the price, from the flooding back home in Ireland to the heat waves here. We don’t have to choose between a healthy environment and a healthy economy—good climate policy should invest in clean energy, green jobs, and public health so working people and retirees alike can thrive. I’d rather see us spend money now to protect our air, water, and climate than leave a ruined world to the young volunteers I work with at the community center.

As someone who works in manufacturing and cares deeply about both my community and the environment, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need policies that push companies to innovate cleaner processes rather than just slow production. Climate policy should set strong, science-based limits on pollution and invest in green technology and worker retraining so that people like me can keep stable jobs while our industries become more sustainable.

As someone who works in trucking and depends on a strong economy to support my family, I don’t think protecting the environment and economic growth have to be at odds—we just need smart policies that help both. Climate policy should push cleaner technologies, more efficient logistics, and sustainable practices in transportation, while also supporting workers with training and good jobs so people like me aren’t left behind.

Como alguien que trabajó duro toda su vida y ahora vive con ingresos fijos, creo que debemos cuidar la creación de empleo y el costo de la energía al mismo tiempo que protegemos la creación de Dios. Apoyo medidas ambientales que sean razonables, que no destruyan los negocios pequeños ni suban demasiado las cuentas de luz y gasolina para familias como la mía. Para mí, la solución es avanzar poco a poco con nuevas tecnologías limpias, sin imponer reglas extremas que dañen la economía y la estabilidad de las comunidades trabajadoras.

As an attorney and a lifelong Californian who spends his free time outdoors, I see environmental protection and economic growth not as opposing interests, but as interests that must be harmonized through smart, evidence-based policy. Climate policy should set firm, enforceable standards that internalize environmental costs—so that businesses cannot simply externalize pollution—while also providing clear, predictable regulatory frameworks and incentives that foster innovation, green jobs, and long-term economic stability.

My mamá says we have to take care of the air and the trees so I can keep playing outside and drawing sunny skies, so I think protecting nature has to come first. Grown‑ups should make money in ways that don’t make the weather scary or hurt animals, even if it means changing how they do things.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin our air, water, and climate, there won’t be a healthy future or real economy for my generation. But I don’t think it has to be “environment vs. jobs” – the government and businesses should invest in clean energy, green jobs, and helping communities, especially Black communities that are often hit hardest by pollution, transition fairly. As a Catholic, I’ve learned we’re supposed to be good stewards of God’s creation and care for the poor, so climate policies should focus on both protecting the Earth and making sure families can still work, learn, and live with dignity.

As a mother and a homemaker, I want clean air, safe water, and a stable climate for my kids, but I also know families like mine depend on steady jobs and affordable energy. I believe we should support practical, market-based solutions—like incentives for cleaner technologies, conservation, and responsible use of resources—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for working families. To me, the right balance is encouraging innovation and personal responsibility, not heavy-handed regulations that hurt our economy and our communities.

At my age, I’ve lived long enough to see what happens when we treat the earth as expendable in the name of short‑term profit, and it troubles me deeply. I believe climate policy must put environmental protection first, because a damaged planet will ultimately undercut any economic growth, but we should cushion working people and small businesses through this transition with strong social supports and new green jobs. As a Catholic and a Democrat, I see caring for creation and safeguarding vulnerable communities as moral obligations, not optional add‑ons, and I’m willing to pay a bit more or change habits if it means leaving a livable world behind.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we wreck the planet now there won’t be any future economy for my generation to grow up into. But I also get that people need jobs and money, so I’d rather see us invest in cleaner technologies and energy that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting everything down.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because animals and trees can’t fix things if we break them, but people can still find new ways to make money that don’t hurt the Earth so much. Grown‑ups should spend more money and time on clean energy and safer factories, even if it’s a little harder at first, because we’re the ones who have to live here when we grow up.

We need a balance where we protect the land and air we all depend on, but don’t crush small businesses and working folks with regulations and costs they can’t handle. Climate policies should focus on practical solutions like cleaner, more efficient technology and American-made energy, not blanket rules dreamed up by people who’ve never worked a day on a job site. I’m all for being good stewards of God’s creation, but we’ve got to keep the economy strong and jobs here at home while we do it.

I think we have to stop acting like protecting the environment and growing the economy are opposites, because a wrecked climate will destroy jobs and communities anyway. Climate policy should push us toward clean energy, conservation, and green infrastructure, even if that means some industries change or shrink, and we should invest in helping workers and towns transition so people aren’t left behind.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we ignore pollution and the environment, and I don’t want my grand-nieces and nephews growing up in a world that’s burning or flooding just so a few companies can keep their profits up. I think we need strong climate rules that put people’s health and the planet first, and then help workers and small businesses adapt with things like job training and clean-energy investments. Economic growth that destroys our air, water, and weather isn’t really “growth” at all—it’s a bill our kids will have to pay.

We need to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that wrecks jobs, public safety budgets, and working people’s cost of living. I’d support climate policies that push practical innovation—like cleaner energy, efficiency, and better infrastructure—as long as they’re grounded in real-world data, don’t crush small businesses, and keep America energy independent.

I think we need to protect God’s creation, but we also have to be honest that working folks like me can’t afford higher gas and electric bills in the name of climate policy. I support common‑sense steps that reduce pollution and encourage cleaner energy, as long as they don’t shut down jobs or make it harder for parents to provide for their kids. We should focus on practical, affordable solutions—like improving efficiency and supporting American energy—rather than sweeping regulations that hurt small communities and working families.

I don’t think it should be “environment vs. economy” like they’re enemies, because a wrecked climate will destroy way more jobs and opportunities in the long run than any short‑term growth we get from polluting. Climate policy should push businesses and communities to go green fast—like investing in clean energy, public transit, and sustainable products—while also helping workers and small businesses adapt so people don’t get left behind. As someone who cares about both the planet and having a stable future job, I’d rather see smart, fair climate rules now than wait until the damage is so bad that fixing it costs way more and hits regular people the hardest.

I believe we have a responsibility from God to be good stewards of the earth, but we also have to be practical and protect people’s livelihoods and our economy. Climate policies should encourage cleaner energy and conservation where it makes sense, without crippling small businesses, raising utility bills too high, or killing jobs for working families. We should focus on common-sense measures, new technology, and gradual changes that balance caring for the environment with keeping America strong and prosperous.

As someone who works in public-sector management and cares a lot about evidence and long-term systems, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—smart climate policy can and should drive a more resilient, innovative economy. We should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions, strict environmental standards, and large-scale investment in clean energy and green infrastructure, while providing real transition support for workers and communities dependent on fossil-fuel industries. If we ignore climate risks to chase short-term growth, we’re just offloading massive economic and human costs onto the future, and that’s fiscally and morally irresponsible.

Working in the power industry, I see every day that we can’t pretend the economy and the environment are separate—when storms knock out our grid or heat waves spike demand, people’s bills, jobs, and safety are all on the line. Climate policy should push aggressively toward cleaner energy and efficiency, but with strong protections for workers and low-income communities so the costs of transition don’t fall on those who already struggle. As a Democrat and a Catholic, I believe we have a moral duty to care for creation and for each other, which means investing in green technology, modernizing infrastructure, and training workers for new roles instead of clinging to outdated, polluting systems. Economic growth should come from building a more sustainable, resilient future, not from sacrificing our health and our planet for short-term profit.

As someone who makes a living in a creative field and spends a lot of time outside, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies—good climate policy should drive new industries, better design, and more sustainable jobs. We should put strong limits on pollution and carbon, then support innovation and green infrastructure so businesses can adapt and thrive within those guardrails. If we don’t prioritize the climate first, there won’t be a stable economy—or a livable environment—to grow in anyway.

I believe we are called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so that climate policies don’t crush working families and small businesses. We should pursue reasonable, gradual measures—like encouraging cleaner technology and conservation—without heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs or drive up energy costs for people on fixed incomes like mine.

I think we’ve got to be smart and practical about climate policy—protecting the environment matters, but so do people’s jobs and cost of living. Instead of extreme rules that could shut down businesses or spike prices, we should push for cleaner technologies, energy efficiency, and realistic standards that companies can actually meet. If we focus on solutions that cut emissions while keeping the economy strong, we can make real progress without wrecking working people’s livelihoods.

I think climate policy has to put the environment first, because if we trash the planet there won’t even be an economy left for my generation to work in. Businesses shouldn’t be allowed to dump their costs on everyone else by ruining the air and water just to make a bigger profit. I think we should take care of the Earth first, because if the air and water get too dirty, people and animals can’t be healthy or happy. Grown-ups should make new kinds of jobs and machines that don’t hurt the planet so much, so people can still earn money while we keep nature safe.

I think we should take care of the Earth first, because if the air and water get too dirty or the weather gets too crazy, people and animals will get hurt and then we can’t really have good jobs or money anyway. At this point in my life, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies—especially not in a place like Maine where our natural beauty is the backbone of property values and local business. As someone who works in manufacturing and supports a family, I think climate policy has to protect the environment without crippling the industries that put food on the table. As a teacher, a mom, and an immigrant who’s seen both poverty and opportunity up close, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposite goals anymore. True growth today means clean air, secure jobs in sustainable industries, and a livable planet for our students and our own children.

As a nurse and a mom, I see climate policy first as a public health issue, not an abstract economic debate. That doesn’t mean ignoring workers; it means funding serious transition programs, retraining, and community support so people aren’t left behind. Economic growth should be measured in healthier communities, stable ecosystems, and resilient jobs, not just quarterly profits.

Working in chemical manufacturing and trying to raise young kids in a world that’s clearly warming, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need smart climate policies that push cleaner technologies and safer processes while keeping good jobs here in Michigan. I think we should protect the environment first, because if the planet gets too hot or polluted, people and animals will suffer and there won’t be a good future for kids like me. At my age, I’ve seen that when we ignore the environment in the name of “growth,” we just end up paying a bigger bill later—whether it’s in health problems, disasters, or lost livelihoods. At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of the land, air, and water we all depend on, and we simply can’t keep kicking the can down the road. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, but done in a smart way that creates new jobs, supports workers in dirty industries to transition, and helps low- and middle-income folks with the costs. At this late stage of both my life and our planet’s climate trajectory, it’s clear to me that “balancing” environmental protection and economic growth is a false choice: a stable climate and intact ecosystems are the foundation of any durable economy. Climate policy should put firm ecological limits first—rapid decarbonization, habitat protection, and strict pollution controls—while using smart regulation, public investment, and just transition programs to guide markets and workers into genuinely sustainable forms of growth.

I believe we need a practical balance where we protect God’s creation without strangling small businesses and working folks with red tape. As a science teacher and someone who tries to live lightly on the planet, I don’t really see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—long-term economic health depends on a stable climate and intact ecosystems. Climate policy should put strong limits on pollution and invest aggressively in clean energy, efficiency, and public transit, even if that means higher costs up front, because that creates good jobs and protects our communities in the long run. As a public school teacher who cares deeply about my students’ futures, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because there’s no real “economy” on a planet with destabilized ecosystems.
